item.title: Abstract and Interface in C#
item.description: An abstract class in C# is a class marked with the abstract keyword that may contain abstract and non-abstract members (methods, properties, events, etc.).

item.title: Learn C# from Scratch: A Complete Course for Absolute Beginners
item.description: Ready to start your coding journey? If youâ€™ve never programmed before, this C# course is tailor-made for you.

item.title: Introduction to C#
item.description: C# is a **general-purpose, type-safe, object-oriented programming language**. It was designed with **programmer productivity** in mind, providing a modern and efficient way to develop software applications.

item.title: Single Responsibility Principle
item.description: At its core, SRP advocates that a class should have a **single reason to change**, meaning it should only have one responsibility. Essentially, a class should encapsulate one aspect of the functionality within the software. By adhering to this principle, the design becomes more modular, maintainable, and easier to extend.

item.title: Mastering SOLID Principles in C#, Building Robust and Maintainable Applications
item.description: SOLID is an acronym representing five essential design principles introduced by Robert C. Martin to guide software developers in writing maintainable and scalable code. Each principle addresses a specific aspect of software design, focusing on enhancing the maintainability, extensibility, and reusability of the codebase.

item.title: Delegates Part 2
